head.title: Old and New Will Meet As Jets Open Minicamp

hedline.hl1: Old and New Will Meet As Jets Open Minicamp

abstract.p: New York Jets three-day minicamp opens, allowing veteran players and coaches to meet newly acquired players (M)

block.p: The Jets might consider handing out ''Hi, My Name Is. . . . '' stickers this morning when their three-day minicamp opens because, more than anything else, it will serve as a protracted meet and greet.

The Jets's three-day minicamp will serve as a protracted meet and greet for new and old players.

The Jets might consider handing out ''Hi, My Name Is. . . . '' stickers this morning when their three-day minicamp opens because, more than anything else, it will serve as a protracted meet and greet.
Five draft picks and seven players signed as free agents will gather with the rest of the squad at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y. Of those 12 players, 9 play defense.
The Jets have overhauled their defense and there is a chance they could have seven new starters this season, including three of the four members of the secondary.
Although most of the veterans have already been working out at the Jets' complex, this is the first chance to see them and the rookies on the field together.
Last season, there were concerns within the organization about communication breakdowns among defensive players, leading, inevitably, to coverage breakdowns.
The task during the minicamp and the off-season conditioning program is to meld players from so many different teams into a cohesive unit.

''A lot comes from hanging, besides thinking about football, just getting to know each other and how each other reacts in certain situations,'' said cornerback Aaron Beasley, a free agent from Jacksonville. ''We've been doing a lot of that. We call it hanger-flying. We actually sit together and eat lunch together and find out each other's personalities and that really opens communications.''
Although the Jets hope to land another veteran defensive tackle -- they signed Riddick Parker and drafted Alan Harper -- the transformation of the defense is nearly complete.

In the moments after the draft ended, Coach Herman Edwards spoke of a plan to switch the focus of the defense from girth to speed. Edwards wants to play a brand of defense that emphasizes pressure on the quarterback and swarming linemen.
With the drafting of the speedy defensive end Bryan Thomas in the first round and safety Jon McGraw in the second, the plan became evident.
''With the guys we've gotten, we've done some good things,'' Edwards said. ''We're different now.''

Safety Sam Garnes, the former Giant, said: ''This team, they're known for their offense. Offense are the head honchos here. I think things are going to even up a little bit. We had a lot of defensive players added to this team and we feel we have to dominate.''
